title: FAA Proposes Fines on Boeing, Southwest
summary: Aircraft maker allegedly used defective wing parts on some 737 MAX jets that it maintained were ready for service. U.S. regulators on Friday proposed an additional fine on Boeing Co. for its alleged use of defective wing parts on some 737 MAX jets that it maintained were ready for service.

title: The Economy's Inequality Dividend
summary: Growth is lifting low-income workers and the middle class.. The December employment report on Friday was a modest disappointment with fewer new jobs and slowing wage gains. But the report is an exception to other strong recent labor data, and the big picture is that the longest hiring expansion in 80 years is lifting lower-income workers in particular as accumulating evidence shows.

title: U.S. Adds New Limits on Cuba Travel
summary: Move ends public charter flights between America and nine Cuban destinations, though not Havana. WASHINGTON-The State Department said Friday that public charter flights between the U.S. and most Cuban destinations-though not the nation's main city, Havana-would be suspended in an effort to reduce the Cuban government's revenue, another step in the Trump administration's move to clamp down on the island.

title: The Trumped-Up Case of Bar v. Barr
summary: New York lawyers want the AG investigated for political disagreements.. The legal bar is supposed to be a professional group that enforces standards for lawyers, yet it increasingly seems to be one more partisan political outfit. The latest example is the New York City Bar Association's letter to Congress demanding it "investigate" Attorney General Bill Barr for making conservative political statements.

title: America's Conservative Plurality
summary: The share of Americans who say they are liberal declined in 2019.. One major political trend of the past generation is the rising number of Americans who identify as liberal. This has led to predictions of an "emerging Democratic majority" fueled by young and minority voters as well as a bunker mentality on parts of the right.

title: 'A Sweet and Too Short Dream'
summary: In an era of media failures, a reporter who left readers wanting more.. Recent history has brought no shortage of media failings. But recent news also provides a reminder of what a good reporter can do.

title: 'A New World Begins' Review: Cake for the Commoner
summary: 1789 saw the revolt of France's 95% against the king, the clergy and the nobility.. When the representatives of the Estates-General met in the glittering Hôtel des Menus-Plaisirs in Versailles on May 5, 1789, there was every reason to believe that the French stood on the threshold of a new era. Louis XVI had summoned the ancient body to address a financial crisis that threatened the kingdom with bankruptcy and left many wondering whether France was still capable of pursuing its great goal of supplanting Britain as the world's dominant power.

title: 'Oldest' Bar in New York City Avoids Last Call
summary: Neir's Tavern opened in 1829 near the former Union Course racetrack in Queens. Neir's Tavern, the self-proclaimed oldest bar in New York City, will avoid closing after the owner of the Queens establishment and its landlord reached a last-minute deal on Friday, according to city officials.

title: Thomas Mann's Message for America in the Digital Age
summary: In 1938 he was optimistic about democracy. But he also warned against taking it for granted.. In the last days of the year I found myself alone in a corner of my mother's small library. She had recently gone through a cleaning phase, which involved a better organization of her volumes. In front of me was her shelf of Thomas Mann, the German writer. Next to "The Magic Mountain" and "Buddenbrooks" rested a dark volume, slim and frayed, its title etched in leather: "The Coming Victory of Democracy." I lifted it gently, flipping through its yellowed, brittle pages. In 1938 Mann had embarked on a lecture tour in the U.S.; this was a bound volume of his speeches.

title: Anatomy of a Witch Hunt, Revisited
summary: Kudos to a Washington Post writer for holding the media's feet to the fire over the Steele dossier.. Erik Wemple, the Washington Post's media critic, has produced an 11-part series (so far) on the press's handling of the Steele dossier in the wake of its debunking by Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz.

title: Pete Buttigieg's Essay Contest
summary: The candidate resembles Barack Obama in his pitch for unity and feel-good progressivism. But can a white male Democrat pull off the same magic?. Manchester, N.H.

title: Early Impeachments in 2020 Hindsight
summary: If you think the process too political now, consider how the Jeffersonians handled it in 1804.. If you think impeachment is too political in 2020, remember 1804. That year saw two impeachments, one of which led to a trial of a Supreme Court justice, presided over by a vice president who had just killed a former Treasury secretary in a duel.

title: Philadelphia's Top Prosecutor Pursues 'Social,' Not Actual, Justice
summary: Larry Krasner said he wouldn't prosecute certain offenses and the bad guys got the message.. Michael White didn't deny killing Sean Schellenger. He admitted to police and at his trial that he plunged a knife several times into Schellenger's back during a July 2018 scuffle in Philadelphia's Rittenhouse Square. Numerous witnesses and a cellphone video confirmed what happened. Yet in October 2019 a jury acquitted Mr. White, a 22-year-old college student, of voluntary manslaughter. Many, including the victim's family, blame Larry Krasner, Philadelphia's soft-on-crime district attorney.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb, Macy's, Grubhub: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.

title: 'Bubble in the Sun' Review: How Do You Like Them Oranges?
summary: The rafﬁsh story of the Florida land boom of the 1920s-and how it helped bring on the Great Depression.. It is difficult to go wrong when writing of questionable behavior and wretched excess in Florida, a fact that is borne out yet again in Christopher Knowlton's colorful "Bubble in the Sun," a wide-ranging treatment of the ill-fated South Florida land boom of the 1920s. Mr. Knowlton, a former staff writer and London bureau chief for Fortune magazine, provides a close look into the exploits of a number of legendary players central to the meteoric rise and fall of the state's fortunes in the first third of the 20th century. He concludes with the provocative assertion that the very cause of the Great Depression was not the crash of the stock market in 1929 but the collapse of the overheated development frenzy in Florida, which began to show signs of stress in late 1925.

title: Investigation Into Carillion Audits to Take Longer Than Expected
summary: The scale and complexity of the probe into the U.K. construction company's collapse is 'exceptional,' regulator says. The U.K. Financial Reporting Council said Friday that its investigation into the audits of Carillion PLC's financial statements would take longer than expected, highlighting the complexity of its probe into the British construction and services company's collapse.

title: Report Faults MIT Administrators for Accepting Epstein Donations
summary: The late financier and convicted sex offender donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to school. Top administrators at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were aware for years that Jeffrey Epstein, the financier and convicted sex offender, donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to MIT, a law firm hired by the school found.

title: Casper to Test Sleepy IPO Market
summary: Company filing reveals heavy losses to go along with sharp revenue growth. Casper Sleep Inc. hopes it can wake the IPO market from its slumber.

title: Alphabet's Legal Chief to Depart
summary: David Drummond was alleged to have had inappropriate relations with staff at Google. The chief legal officer of Google parent Alphabet Inc. is leaving the company amid an investigation into his relationships with employees of the search-engine giant.

title: Brexit Propels Deal to Revive Northern Ireland's Assembly
summary: Parties in U.K. province agree to reconvene; 'Route No. 1 to having any real power'. LONDON-The U.K.'s looming departure from the European Union has driven Northern Ireland's uneasy bedfellows back together.

title: House to Send Impeachment Articles to Senate Next Week
summary: Ending delay, speaker to prepare resolution that would initiate President Trump's trial. WASHINGTON-Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) said the House would move forward next week on sending the articles of impeachment to the Senate, ending a tense standoff and setting the stage for the trial of President Trump, the third of its kind in the nation's history.

title: U.S. Targeted, Missed Senior Iranian Commander in Yemen, Officials Say
summary: Operation occurred at the time of the killing of Iranian General Soleimani. WASHINGTON-The U.S. military targeted but failed to kill a senior Iranian military commander in Yemen around the time it conducted the drone strike that killed an Iranian general in Iraq, U.S. officials said.

title: U.S. Government Bond Prices Rise Following Labor Report
summary: Data show economy added fewer jobs than expected. U.S. government bond prices advanced Friday after data showed the economy added fewer jobs than expected.

title: As Jobs Cap Decade of Gains, Women Are Workforce Majority
summary: U.S. added 145,000 jobs in December, marking longest stretch of annual increases in 80 years of data. WASHINGTON-Women overtook men to hold the majority of U.S. jobs for the first time in a decade, while employers added positions for a record 10th straight year, pointing to a growing and dynamic economy heading into 2020.

title: Trump Administration Weighs Tighter Requirements for Disability Payments
summary: Older workers would be among those most affected. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is working on a plan to tighten eligibility requirements for disability benefits, especially for older Americans, the latest step in a broader White House effort to shrink federal safety-net programs.

title: Farmers Reap Big Harvest After Tough Year
summary: Corn and soybean production topped expectations despite bad weather. Farmers are harvesting more corn and soybeans than expected this season, lifting prospects for a sector hurt by bad weather and trade tensions.

title: Virginia Lawmakers Ban Guns at State Capitol
summary: Planned Jan. 20 rally expected to draw gun-rights and gun-control advocates. Lawmakers in Virginia banned firearms at the state Capitol, adding new regulations ahead of a pro-gun rally expected in Richmond on Jan. 20.

title: Dow Industrials Pull Back After Crossing 29000 for First Time
summary: Economy added jobs for 10th straight year, hiring pace slows in December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average briefly jumped past the 29000 milestone for the first time Friday but hit resistance after a dramatic three-month rally.

title: Trump's Tax Reform Is Helping Most People
summary: The historic surplus in job openings, about seven million today, has allowed lower- and middle-income workers to bid up their wages and salaries.. Regarding "Taking Stock of the Tax Overhaul's Impact" (Exchange, Jan. 4): On some measures, such as business investment, the numbers have fallen short of expectations. But as someone who helped design the tax plan for Donald Trump, I can say definitively that his primary goal was to raise incomes for middle-class families. Period. The purpose of the tax cut was to make American businesses more competitive and profitable by lowering their highest-in-the-world income-tax rates and through a lower tax on $1 trillion of foreign capital repatriated into the U.S. We believed this would increase the demand for workers and capital investment, which would drive up wages.

title: Beyond Meat's Shares Had Their Best Week in Months
summary: Plant-based meat substitute company log biggest weekly gain since July. It was a remarkable week for Beyond Meat Inc.

title: GM to Revive Hummer Name on New Electric Pickup Model
summary: Vehicle is expected to go on sale by early 2022. General Motors Co. is resurrecting the Hummer name on an all-electric pickup truck to be sold under the GMC brand, according to people familiar with the matter, reviving a once-popular yet controversial badge that was phased out a decade ago.

title: Blame the e-Cigarette Firms for Teen Vaping
summary: The blame lies squarely on the e-cigarette companies and the regulators that failed to recognize the danger, not with the medical community.. As a pediatrician and a longtime advocate for protecting children from nicotine, tobacco and marijuana, I disagree with your editorial ("Thank You for Not Vaping," Jan. 3) point about one reason for the increase in youth vaping. The blame lies squarely on the e-cigarette companies and the regulators who failed to recognize the danger, not with the medical community that has been raising concerns amid growing evidence of youth addiction.

title: Wasn't Anti-Semitism a Thing of the Past?
summary: No one should feel unsafe identifying themselves as belonging to a particular race or religion in America.. I cried reading Abigail Shrier's, "Yale, Al Sharpton and the Attacks on New York's Jews" (Cross Country, Jan. 4). As the granddaughter of four Holocaust concentration-camp survivors, I am horrified by the amount of anti-Semitic attacks that have occurred in such a short period. No one should feel unsafe identifying themselves as belonging to a particular race or religion in America.

title: Cyber War May Intensify And We Should Be Prepared
summary: With cyber weapons, we could begin to lose a consciousness of the human cost of war.. In light of the recent drone attack in Iraq, the article "Congress Wants Clarity on Cyber Warfare" (U.S. News, Dec. 31) is more timely than ever. The American public also wants more clarity. Indeed, cyber warfare, notably drones, could make it easier to conduct a war and possibly even to go to war. Cyber weapons often are positioned as potentially saving lives that would have otherwise been committed to action. And dollars are easier to expend than human lives. However, with cyber weapons, we could begin to lose a consciousness of the human cost of war, something that has generally guided our thinking regarding conflicts for the last century. Let us not lose that sense.

title: The Sociology of Reactions To Gen. Soleimani's Killing
summary: The most interesting thing about the letters to the editor on the conflict with Iran is their sociological information.. The most interesting thing about the letters on the conflict with Iran ("Next Steps for U.S. After Soleimani's Demise," Jan. 9) is the varied reactions: Two guys from Maryland gave the technical/government viewpoint, two from the South said we should kick Iran's behind, the Californian said, "Chill, dudes!" and the New Yorker related it to burglars kidnapping Alexa.

title: Are We Ready for Joe Biden as Commander in Chief?
summary: The former vice president touts his foreign-policy expertise, but his record is dubious. The unwaveringly faulty conventional wisdom of electoral politics told us this week that when the drums of war sound, voters gravitate toward candidates with governing experience. That didn't work for Hillary Clinton in 2008 with her "3 a.m. phone call," but some pundits and partisans are arguing that the uncertain reverberations from the liquidation of Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani last week will see voters clutching the apron strings of Steady Joe Biden, whose five decades in Washington mark him as the most seasoned potential president on offer.

title: A Historic Los Angeles Neighborhood Hit by the Getty Fire
summary: Scenes from the Crestwood Hills neighborhood of Los Angeles, where restored midcentury modern homes are intermingled with burned remains.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Hong Kong Property Investor Set to Make Record Purchase in London
summary: A central-London home to sell for just under $274 million, in what would be the U.K.'s most expensive house sale. A Hong Kong real-estate investor is set to buy a central-London residential property for just under £210 million ($274 million), in what would be the U.K.'s most expensive house sale ever.

title: Navy Reports Aggressive Encounter With Russian Ship in Mideast
summary: The Russian vessel ultimately changed course after the USS Farragut sounded a warning signal.

title: Oil Logs Worst Week Since July as Iran Tensions Ease
summary: Despite fallout from the U.S. airstrike in the Middle East, oil prices slid 6% as traders focused on supply. Oil prices finished their largest weekly drop in nearly six months Friday despite recent tensions between the U.S. and Iran, underscoring bets that geopolitics in the Middle East won't disrupt the world's crude supplies and threaten the world economy.

title: Iraq Considers Purchase of Russian Air-Defense Missile System
summary: S-400 system is same that Turkey bought, in move that strained NATO relations. Members of the Iraqi parliament said the country was considering the purchase of a Russian air-defense system as the Kremlin moves to step up its presence in the Middle East and drive a wedge between Baghdad and Washington.

title: Parcel Carriers, Truckers Slashed Jobs in December
summary: Delivery and warehousing companies expanded payrolls over the full year at the slowest rate since 2013. Transportation companies slashed jobs in December, as logistics providers that are focused on e-commerce fulfillment retrenched and truckers pulled back in response to slowing industrial freight demand.

title: RH Chief Nails Down $37 Million Buy in Beverly Hills
summary: Gary Friedman, head of the company formerly known as Restoration Hardware, bought the roughly 11,000-square-foot mansion from a limited liability company tied to the former chairman of Northrop Grumman. Gary Friedman, chief executive of furnishings companyRH, may be in the market for some new home-goods himself, having recently purchased a Beverly Hills estate for $37 million, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Restoration Hardware Chief's Beverly Hills Home
summary: Gary Friedman paid $37 million for this property that has Hollywood Regency and Palm Beach influences.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Luxe Ski Cabins in the Middle of Nowhere: A Booking Guide
summary: Cushy backcountry huts, long a staple in Europe's Alps, are finally making their way to the U.S.. THE FIRST TIME I stayed at a mountain ski hut, it was the stuff of winter dreams: a remote cabin with a wood stove surrounded by fresh, deep snow and pristine peaks-without another soul in sight. Other aspects of that trip were less dreamy. It took me and three friends all day to reach that small, austere hut, in Wyoming's Rocky Mountains. We skied some 12 miles from the trailhead, gaining a few thousand feet in elevation, our backpacks laden with food for a week, sleeping bags, emergency rescue and avalanche gear. When we arrived, we had to cut the firewood with a crosscut saw, and sleep in a loft like sardines. It was deliriously fun, but I was hardly surprised that we had the week of glorious powder skiing all to ourselves.

title: Boeing Supplier to Lay Off 2,800
summary: Freeze on Boeing 737 MAX forces Spirit AeroSystems to cut back. The biggest Boeing Co. 737 MAX supplier said it is planning an initial 2,800 layoffs, the first announced job cuts since the grounding of a plane that is rippling through the broader aerospace industry.

title: Your Gym Outfit Might Be Too Boring
summary: Fashion-focused athletic wear from bedazzled bras to leopard-print leggings is rivaling basic-black performance gear. But is it fitting for fitness?. YOU NEED ALL new workout clothes," a trainer told me back in 2009. I'd just joined a swanky New York City gym with an unspoken dress code. My baggy yellow T-shirt and electric purple tights clearly did not comply. Embarrassed by me, for me, or both, he suggested I visit Lululemon an outlet of the now-ubiquitous lifestyle brand-where I bought an all-black outfit comprising leggings, a tank and a sports bra. I headed back to the gym and blended right in, like a sweaty, goth lemming.

title: Republican Lawmaker Apologizes for Saying Democrats Love Terrorists
summary: Rep. Doug Collins made the comments as Congress debated president's use of military force against Iran. Republican Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia apologized on Friday for accusing Democrats of being "in love with terrorists," a comment that came as Congress engaged in an emotional debate over whether to rein in presidential war powers.

title: Modern Vindication for an Ancient Flop
summary: Euripides' 'Medea' finally found its place in the repertory because of his superb talent for writing from a woman's point of view.. Standard commentaries on "Medea" inform the reader that Euripides' tragedy won the third prize at its premiere at the Dionysia festival in Athens, in 431 B.C., yet often fail to mention that there were only three playwrights in competition. Euripides had previously taken the top prize (a wreath of ivy), and would do so again, but insofar as it's possible to reconstruct ancient box office, his grisly tale of a woman who wreaks vengeance on a faithless husband by murdering their young children was a bomb.

title: Endo Agrees to Pay $8.8 Million to Settle Oklahoma Opioid Case
summary: State attorney general praises company for taking early steps to mitigate crisis. Endo Pharmaceuticals Inc. agreed to pay roughly $8.8 million to settle claims by the state of Oklahoma that the company's marketing played a role in the opioid abuse crisis.

title: The Job Market's Manufactured Weakness
summary: Troubles in the manufacturing sector are cutting into job growth. It is a problem that won't end soon.. The job market weakened last month, and that had a lot to do with what is happening in manufacturing.

title: Women Overtake Men as Majority of U.S. Workforce
summary: Data reflect growth in services industries that employ higher numbers of women. WASHINGTON-Women held more U.S. jobs than men in December for the first time in nearly a decade, a development that likely reflects the future of the American workforce.

title: The Sinister Genius of Qassem Soleimani
summary: The Iranian commander harnessed both Shiite extremists and Sunni radicals, even as he built a 'foreign legion' to project Iran's power. In 2003, in the run-up to the U.S.-led invasion of Iraq, the Iranian regime was ridden with anxiety. President George W. Bush had included Iran in his post-9/11 "axis of evil" in a famous 2002 speech. I interviewed many Iranian officials at the time as a Tehran-based analyst with the International Crisis Group, and I vividly remember their fear that the U.S. might turn next to Tehran.

title: SARS Experience Guided China's Effort to Contain New Virus
summary: Early diagnosis and strict quarantines of those sickened at Wuhan food market have helped limit outbreak. WUHAN, China-A respiratory virus that has sickened dozens and killed one person in central China has put other regions and nearby countries on alert. Here at the center of the crisis, experience with the deadly SARS virus and what appears to be a less virulent outbreak have helped in containing the threat.

title: Marianne Williamson Ends Democratic Presidential Campaign
summary: Author struggled in field of veteran politicians and was scrutinized for her past comments. Author Marianne Williamson, who moved to Des Moines in hopes of making a splash at the Iowa caucuses, said she was suspending her Democratic campaign for president.

title: Wanna Bet? The Market Has a View on the 2020 Election
summary: Futures markets, and betting books, for the U.S. presidential race are in full swing. Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our new newsletter, "2020 Election+Business," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election. You can sign up here.

title: Don't Get Punk'd by Celebrity Investor Wealth
summary: Movie stars and athletes are rich, but not nearly as rich as a report about their startup investments in companies like Uber, Lyft and Impossible Foods suggests. Either the syndication rights from "That '70s Show" are really, really lucrative or someone has been taking liberties.

title: How Bernie Sanders Stumbled, Then Steadied His Presidential Campaign
summary: Vermont senator moves to the top in Iowa, with the state's caucuses less than a month away. ANAMOSA, Iowa-In the days surrounding Bernie Sanders's heart attack on the campaign trail, his support dipped, at the same time as liberal rival Elizabeth Warren was surging into a near tie with Joe Biden for the lead. The Vermont senator's chances for the Democratic presidential nomination seemed dim.

title: John Mulaney's New Audience
summary: A rising comedian's fondness for 'Sesame Street' helped inspire a Netflix special aimed at children. "Ernie was the first thing I ever saw that was funny," says the comedian and "Saturday Night Live" veteran John Mulaney as he digs into a breakfast of Honey Nut Cheerios. "The only other variety show to work as well as 'SNL' is 'Sesame Street.' It's really random and really eclectic-like 1-2-3-4, and then they'd cut to a crayon factory, and then they'd be back playing pickup basketball."

title: Burger, Mustard, Banana: It's Not Lunch, It's Your New Reading List
summary: Ever since 'Cod,' one-word titles on one commodity take off. Elaine Khosrova was once asked to sample two dozen chunks of butter in one sitting. The result? A book idea.

title: U.S.-Iran Tensions Have Dampened the Middle East's Protest Movement
summary: Hostility between Washington and Tehran has made it harder for protesters in Iran and Iraq to press for political change.. CAIRO-The spike in tensions between the U.S. and Iran has made it harder for pro-democracy movements to press for more political freedoms in Iran, Iraq and across the Middle East, even if the desire for change is seldom far from the surface.

title: Federal Reserve Sent Lower Remittances to U.S. Treasury in 2019
summary: The Fed paid $10 billion less to the government last year after repurchase activities drove up costs. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve payments to the U.S. Treasury declined in 2019 to a decade low, as the central bank's expenses rose and income declined.

title: Apple and Microsoft Are Dazzling Investors. That Won't Last.
summary: The shiniest stocks are driving the bull market higher. But rusty old bargains will eventually have their day.. Pop quiz: Name the giant store whose customers scoff at whatever goes on sale, but flock to buy whatever costs the most.

title: How the Kindness of Others Motivates KIND's Founder
summary: Daniel Lubetzky uses his snack-bar company to build bridges between people. Those who help him include a former White House chief of staff..

title: Saving Democracy From the Managerial Elite
summary: To heal our deep social and political divisions, urban professionals must start sharing power with the working class..

title: 'Race of Aces' Review: When Lightning Strikes
summary: The race to become America's highest-scoring fighter pilot was sparked by a new plane and a case of Scotch.. In 1942, the conditions under which the war was being fought by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's forces in the South Pacific were abominable-mud, constant rainstorms, oppressive heat, more mud, bugs, snakes, enormous mountains, impenetrable jungles. And still more mud. Many of the surrounding natives were cannibals. And the bureaucrats managing their supplies weren't much of a help either, hoarding essential supplies and equipment in a warehouse in Melbourne, Australia, instead of sending them to the front. Of the 40 P-39s sitting on the runway at Seven Mile Drome in Port Moresby, New Guinea, only 10 were airworthy. MacArthur's troops were supposed to be protecting Australia from Japanese invasion, but they were sitting ducks whenever a squadron of Japanese fighters flew in for a bombing raid.

title: An Airline Required a Woman to Take a Pregnancy Test to Fly to This U.S. Island
summary: Immigration concerns in Saipan put pressure on airlines to screen their passengers. HONG KONG-Japanese citizen Midori Nishida was checking in to a flight in Hong Kong in November to visit her parents on Saipan, a U.S. island in the Pacific, when airline staff made an unusual demand. She had to take a pregnancy test if she wanted to board.

title: Five Best: James Kaplan on American Songwriters
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Irving Berlin: New York Genius.'. By William McBrien (1998)

title: 'The Great Concert of the Night' Review: Remember You Must Die
summary: For Jonathan Buckley, narratives are something we impose on the disorder of life in order to make sense of what is often inexplicable.. Reviews ofJonathan Buckley's novels, of which there are now 10, often lament that the author toils without literary fame or many readers. When Mr. Buckley won a big short-story award in his native Britain in 2015, some journalists admitted they were learning of him for the first time. There is hope, then, that he is on the verge of breaking through with his latest novel, "The Great Concert of the Night," the first to be published in the United States. But while admirable and frequently beautiful, this cerebral and disorienting book handily illustrates why Mr. Buckley has long been marooned in the commercial no-man's land of writer's writers.

title: 'Horace Greeley' Review: The National Newsman
summary: Horace Greeley's rough-hewn eloquence and unbridled political fervor was loved legions of followers.. In 1831, young Horace Greeley, devoid of money but bubbling with ambition, arrived in New York as a journeyman printer. Ten years later he established the New-York Tribune as a mass circulation penny paper with a distinctive tone of civic rectitude and moral exhortation. The enterprise succeeded spectacularly, and Greeley became the most influential newspaperman of his time, with legions of followers who loved his rough-hewn eloquence and political fervor. In denigrating President Martin Van Buren as he sought re-election, Greeley wrote: "Wherever you find a bitter, blasphemous Atheist and an enemy of Marriage, Morality, and Social Order, there you may be certain of one vote for Van Buren."

title: 'Life in a Cold Climate' Review: A Life of Great Compensations
summary: Nancy Mitford was an incomparably witty commentator on the vanishing world of the English landed gentry, which she knew intimately.. Nancy Mitford was the eldest of six sisters, the daughters of Lord Redesdale, an impecunious Oxfordshire-based aristocrat known as "Farve" to his children. The girls' unorthodox childhood was enlivened by jokes, or "teases" in the Mitford idiom; batty household economies (when their mother decided to do away with napkins at meals to save money, the headline in the local press was "Peeress Saves Ha'Pence") and idiosyncratic variations on country sports (such as the family "child hunt," during which Farve chased his children across the countryside with bloodhounds). All this became raw material for Nancy's riotous comic (and, to a certain degree, autobiographical) novels.

title: Fiction: The Poetry of Deprivation
summary: A former prisoner in a Soviet labor camp writes from a place beyond embarrassment, beyond fear and beyond consolation. The Soviet writerVarlam Shalamov (1907-82) was arrested by the secret police in 1929. He was released, then arrested again on charges of "Trotskyist activity" in 1937, at the start of Stalin's purges, and returned to the gulag for a sentence that stretched to 15 years. At first he worked to the brink of death in the Arctic gold and coal mines of Kolyma; later he survived in marginally more bearable conditions as a camp paramedic. Released in 1951, he began to write of the experience, ultimately producing (along with a great deal of poetry) six books of first-person, autobiographical short stories. Some of these stories were smuggled out of the U.S.S.R. and published in piecemeal fashion during Shalamov's lifetime, but it is only with the arrival of Donald Rayfield's translation in two fat volumes titled "Kolyma Stories" (New York Review Books, 741 pages, $22.95) and "Sketches of the Criminal World: Further Kolyma Stories" (NYRB, 555 pages, $22.95) that the collections-so remarkable for both their historical witness and their literary integrity-have become fully available to readers of English.

title: 'Me' and 'Rocket Man' Review: A Pop Star of Our Time
summary: Elton John is a reverse Zelig who turns up everywhere, going out of his way to be as conspicuous as possible.. There are three types of fan at an arena rock show: the ones who cheer joyously at the first note of every song; those who cheer when the singer sings the opening line; and the rest, who cheer out of sheer relief when they recognize the chorus.

title: Science Fiction: The Faery Folk of Britain's Magic Forest
summary: Robin Hood, Friar Tuck, the Green Man, Queen Mab. Rachel Atwood's novel is fantasy in an old tradition, rather than the rough-and-tumble of modern epic fantasy.. Rachel Atwood's novel "Walk the Wild With Me" (DAW, 306 pages, $16) has a familiar cast: Little John, Robin Hood, the Sheriff of Nottingham and Friar Tuck. The forest around them, though, is not Sherwood but the magic forest of Old England, where Herne the Huntsman lives, and the Woodwose, and the faeries, who are not pretty little creatures with wings but dangerous, powerful and hostile. The link between the human world and the magic one is Little John, who is also the Green Man, half-tree, half-human (a familiar figure from European myth).

title: Fed Adds Just Over $40 Billion in Temporary Money to Markets
summary: Intervention comes as a weekend repo consisting of $23 billion in Treasurys, $17.9 billion in mortgages. The New York Fed added $40.9 billion in weekend liquidity to financial markets on Friday.

title: Children's Books: New Year's Resolutions for the Little Ones
summary: 'I'll be helpful / when I see someone in need / I won't stand by or hesitate, / I'll get up and take the lead!'. Adults make resolutions to improve themselves each new year. Jessica Hische hopes that small children will make the same sort of vows at bedtime. Using lush typography and whimsical pictures, she provides a template for such self-betterment in "Tomorrow I'll Be Kind" (Penguin Workshop, 32 pages, $17.99).

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended January 4
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Photos of the Week

summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Muni-Bond Shopping Spree Shows No Sign of Stopping
summary: High-income households looking for tax relief drove record inflows into municipal-bond funds in 2019. Investors are heading into this year still eager for municipal bonds after a 2019 buying binge supercharged returns.

title: How to (Elegantly) Hide That Giant TV
summary: A designer outlines her thinking behind this media room's design-revealing her tricks for hiding a television in plain sight. WHEN FIRST RUMINATING on the look of this media room in Jackson Hole, Wyo.-masterminded by locally based CLB Architects-we failed to notice its most brilliant achievement. Completely. We were too distracted by the gutsy color scheme, which blends the muted pale olive-green of the sectional sofa and wallpaper with screamingly primary yellow and red (see: the circular coffee table and pouf from Design Within Reach). That led us to look down at the chunky wool rug and take in how it, too, combines this peculiar trio of colors.

title: Michael Budney Relied on Polish Talent to Make Aircraft Parts in U.S.
summary: Machine shop founder, who reported for work until age 108, sought out immigrants and provided medical care in their own language. He wanted to be a carpenter, but when Michael Budney arrived at a technical school in New Britain, Conn., there were no courses in that trade. So he enrolled in machinery classes. "It was just perfect for me," he said later.

title: Airbnb Looks to Boost Labor Image With Union Pact
summary: Hotel unions have spent millions promoting tighter regulations on the home-sharing giant. Airbnb said Friday it will hire union construction labor for new real-estate developments, the latest sign that the home-sharing company is trying to strengthen its support from organized labor.

title: The Office of Tomorrow
The Fall of Donald Trump's Fixers
summary: The mogul-turned-president has long relied on loyalists to push the limits in defense of his image, but Roy Cohn, David Pecker and Michael Cohen all wound up out in the cold. For decades, Donald Trump has depended on loyalists to take care of especially sensitive and difficult tasks. These guardians of his image-including the Red-baiter Roy Cohn, the tabloid publisher David Pecker and the lawyer Michael Cohen-learned a hard lesson from their service. They pledged fealty to Mr. Trump and dedicated themselves to shielding him. For a while, they became wealthier and more powerful through their association with him. But Mr. Trump ultimately offered little back in protection or respect.

title: Democratic Lawmakers Try to Boost Asian-American Vote in 2020
summary: Republicans also are focusing on the group, saying it benefits from the strong economy. A half-dozen Democratic lawmakers are making plans to travel to battleground states with growing Asian-American and Pacific Islander populations in hopes of boosting the turnout of the Democratic-leaning bloc in the November elections.

title: Realism and Revelation
summary: An exhibition of newly restored panels from Jan van Eyck's Ghent Altarpiece highlights his innovations.. Early Netherlandish artist Jan van Eyck stands front and center in the history of Western art, but much about his life remains in the shadows, from where he was born to how many children he had. There is no doubt, however, that van Eyck (ca. 1390-1441) was the genius behind Belgium's Ghent Altarpiece, an enormous, multipanel work that combines Old and New Testament imagery with depictions of real denizens of 15th-century Flanders.

title: How a Wisconsin Farmer Became the Big Cheese
summary: Pam Hodgson is one of two U.S. women ever to achieve the elite title of master cheesemaker; 'patience is important.'. Pam Hodgson never thought she would make cheese. Now she is one of two women in the U.S. with the prestigious title of "master cheesemaker."

title: The Blessing and Curse of 'Black Gold'
summary: From the pharaohs to John D. Rockefeller, oil has been key to the growth of civilization-but it comes at a high cost.. This January marks the 150th anniversary of the Standard Oil Company, incorporated in 1870 by John D. Rockefeller and three partners. Such was their drive and ruthlessness that within a decade Standard Oil became a vast monopoly, controlling over 90% of America's oil refineries. By 1913 Rockefeller was worth $900 million, the equivalent of $23.6 billion today.

title: Jobs Report Offers Little Reason for Fed to Change Its View
summary: Steady payroll gains but few signs of accelerating wages could keep central bank rate policy on hold. The December employment report is likely to keep the Federal Reserve comfortable with its make-no-moves posture as officials look for evidence that last year's slowdown in manufacturing, investment and trade hasn't spilled into the broader consumer-driven economy.

title: Star Witness Describes Far-Reaching Insider-Trading Scheme
summary: Insider trading is a 'sport' overseas, Marc Demane Debih told investigators. As Marc Demane Debih was flown out of Serbia last May, as a prisoner in U.S. custody, he told federal agents on the plane that an "unbelievable" number of people were committing insider trading. It was a "sport" overseas, Mr. Demane told the agents, according to investigative records described in court. Mr. Demane said he could name names.

title: Airstrikes Hit Iranian Targets in Syria
summary: No one claimed responsibility for the strikes which hit close to the border with Iraq. Airstrikes hit Iranian-backed militias in eastern Syria, killing at least eight fighters and targeting weapons stores and shipments, according to monitoring groups, at a time of heightened tensions between the U.S. and Iran in the region.

title: Canada Labor Market Rebounded in December
summary: Gain in jobs, drop in unemployment rate beat expectations. OTTAWA-Canada added jobs in December and the unemployment rate fell, marking a welcome reprieve for an economy that data indicate was in danger of stalling to end 2019.

title: The Coin Purse Goes Aspirational in a Cash-Free Age
summary: The classic coin purse gets an update from designers such as Louis Vuitton and Marc Jacobs. Louis Vuitton , price upon request, select Louis Vuitton stores

title: How U.S. Messaging Has Changed on the Soleimani Intelligence
summary: Trump administration now emphasizes the deterrent effect as reason for targeted killing of top Iranian military leader. The Trump administration's public explanation of the classified intelligence that prompted it to kill Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani on Jan. 3 has evolved over the past week. President Trump and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo initially stressed that Gen. Soleimani was planning an "imminent" attack against Americans. More recently, Trump administration officials have emphasized the strike's deterrent effect.

title: Lamar Jackson's Quarterback Guru Teaches High-School English
summary: The man behind the NFL's best player doesn't work for the Baltimore Ravens. He teaches teenagers about George Orwell and Huckleberry Finn. Every day, teenagers arrive at St. Thomas Aquinas High School with an odd question for Joshua Harris, an English teacher at the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., school whose students read classics like "1984" and "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" in their sophomore and junior-year classes.

title: Low Liquidity Fueled Hidden Flash Crash in Junk Bonds
summary: While most markets were calm last fall, the market for below-investment-grade corporate debt saw wild price swings. When Party City Holdco Inc. reported a large decline in quarterly earnings in November, holders of the retailer's junk-rated debt scrambled to sell. Buyers were hard to find, and prices cratered by as much as 50% before recovering some of the loss.

title: Google's Restart Could Click With Investors
summary: Better cloud visibility is high on investors' wish list. It is a new day at Google. Just how new remains to be seen.

title: Court Rules Unconstitutional India's Halt of Internet in Disputed Region
summary: Government says it will comply with order to restore services in Muslim-majority Kashmir. NEW DELHI-India's Supreme Court ruled Friday that the indefinite suspension of internet services in Kashmir was unconstitutional, scolding the government for blocking important avenues for communication after its contentious decision last year to end the special status of the Muslim-majority region.

title: LSU: No. 1 in Football-and Drinking Beer
summary: They crush your football team. Then their fans crush your booze.. Louisiana State University fans weren't sure what to expect from this football season. They couldn't have anticipated that quarterback Joe Burrow would win the Heisman Trophy, Ed Orgeron would outcoach Nick Saban or the Tigers would be a heavy favorite in the national championship.

title: Tattoos, Pot and Football: Our Daily Lives Reflected in WSJ/NBC News Polls
summary: Thirty years of surveys capture the changing texture of American life. Would you rather be five years younger or 15 pounds lighter? Does anyone in your home have a tattoo? Which is more harmful to health: a sugar-laden candy bar or a marijuana joint?

title: Valic Says It Pays for Client Referrals
summary: The AIG unit makes arrangements with unions, which then promote its products to members. Valic Financial Advisors Inc., a unit of American International Group Inc., recently disclosed that the firm makes payments to organizations for client referrals and endorsements.

title: The Promise of Sustainable Aviation Fuel Isn't for Today
summary: Sustainable fuels could be a way to reduce the environmental impact of aviation, but much more investment to reduce costs is required. Since electric and hybrid planes won't work at scale for decades, the aviation industry's journey toward a greener future will need to be powered by sustainable fuels. But those with the most promise today might not be good long-term bets.

title: Australian Wildfires Aren't Enough to Burn Out Big Coal
summary: Apocalyptic-looking blazes spell political trouble for big coal companies, but the foundations of the business in Asia run deep. Australia is, and has long been, coal country-among the world's largest exporters of the carbon-heavy fuel. Now, the so-called lucky country is burning on a terrifying scale.

title: Sequoia Is In No Rush to Spend $8 Billion Fund
summary: Venture-capital firm was surprised by fewer opportunities to make large investments. Sequoia Capital set a Silicon Valley record with its $8 billion flagship fund, but the firm isn't in a hurry to spend it.

title: Chinese Developers Flock to Issue Dollar Debt
summary: Demand for higher returns sparks stampede to issue bonds with longer maturities. Chinese property companies have kicked off 2020 by selling billions of dollars of longer-dated bonds, capitalizing on a hot market to reduce their heavy reliance on short-term funding.

title: Oil Producers Are Setting Billions of Dollars on Fire
summary: Resume Subscription. Relatively clean and flexible, natural gas has been described as "the champagne of hydrocarbons." Lately, though, energy companies are treating it about as sparingly as a team that just won the World Series.

title: Amid Craft-Beer Boom, New Drinks Offer Hard Competition
summary: Popularity of spiked seltzers like White Claw and Truly challenges beer makers to respond. It's dry January, when many people abstain from alcohol to improve their health.

title: Who Gets to Play Trump Defender-in-Chief in the Senate?
summary: Republicans focus on who should lead the media strategy in Trump's trial; Senate map improves for Democrats as Pompeo declines to run in Kansas. TRUMP ALLIES PLOT IMPEACHMENT DEFENSE: Indiana Sen. Mike Braun talked with top House Trump defender Mark Meadows before Christmas to discuss who should lead the president's defense both on the Senate floor and in the media. Though some have pushed for Meadows, Jim Jordan or another House firebrand to lead the defense in the Senate, the White House and Majority Leader Mitch McConnell seem to favor a more low-key approach featuring White House lawyers.

title: Landmark Facebook Settlement Still Working Its Way Through Court
summary: Judge orders social-media company, government to file written responses to privacy advocacy groups critical of deal. Almost six months after Facebook Inc. agreed to a $5 billion settlement of privacy violations, the issue is anything but settled for the social-media giant.

summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: Internal Boeing Documents Show Cavalier Attitude to Safety
summary: 'Would you put your family on a MAX simulator trained aircraft? I wouldn't'. Boeing Co. released internal communications that show employees displaying a cavalier attitude toward safety, ridiculing regulators and some airline officials.

title: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle to Step Back as Senior Royals
summary: Duke and Duchess of Sussex say they plan to seek financial independence, spend more time in North America. LONDON-Prince Harry and his wife Meghan Markle said in a surprise statement on Wednesday that they intended to step back as senior members of Britain's royal family-but a response from Buckingham Palace suggested the announcement had caught other members of the family off guard.

title: Jobs Report to Provide Final Look on a Decade of Gains
summary: Economists expect 160,000 jobs were added in the month, with unemployment at 3.5%. The Labor Department will give a broad picture of how the jobs market fared last year with the release of the December jobs report. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal expect employers added jobs at a slower pace during the month while unemployment remained at a 50-year low. Here is what to watch for in the jobs report when it is released Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET.

title: Swiss Back Channel Helped to Defuse U.S.-Iran Crisis
summary: The U.S. sent an encrypted fax via the Swiss Embassy in Tehran urging Iran not to escalate, followed by a flurry of back and forth messages. BERN, Switzerland-Hours after a U.S. strike killed Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani, the Trump administration sent an urgent back channel message to Tehran: Don't escalate.

title: Kim Jong Un Bets Weapons Tests Will Get Trump Talking
summary: After two years of unsuccessful diplomacy, Pyongyang is betting a more-provocative strategy can work. SEOUL-North Korea's flurry of missile launches in 2016 and 2017 attracted a global backlash and a wave of new economic sanctions. But the provocations helped the country land its first-ever summit with a sitting U.S. president.

title: The End of Retirement
summary: The conventional wisdom-save enough to retire at age 65-won't work for the generation starting their careers today, writes columnist John D. Stoll.. Author

title: What We Know About the Iran Plane Crash
summary: Resume Subscription. U.S., Canadian and U.K. officials believe that a Ukrainian commercial aircraft that crashed shortly after takeoff from Tehran on Wednesday, killing all 176 people on board, was downed by a missile system fired by Iran, possibly by mistake. The crash follows Iranian missile strikes against two military bases in Iraq, which Iran said were in retaliation for the U.S. killing of Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani last week.

title: Trump Touts U.S. Iran Strike at Ohio Campaign Rally
summary: President rails against Democrats who questioned his decision to order strike. TOLEDO, Ohio-President Trump touted the recent U.S. strike on an Iranian military leader as "bold and decisive action," and criticized Democrats, as he appeared in the battleground state of Ohio for his kickoff campaign rally of 2020.

title: Threat of Cyberattack by Iran Still Critical, Experts Say
summary: Despite cooling tensions, nation-state-level attacks could occur, according to cybersecurity specialists. SAN DIEGO-The risk of nation-state cyberattacks against U.S. interests remains high amid simmering geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, cybersecurity experts said.

title: Reversal by Trump Revives U.S. Export-Import Bank
summary: Lobbying by president helps U.S. Export-Import Bank, derided by some as 'corporate welfare,' get a 7-year renewal from Congress. WASHINGTON-A U.S. agency that finances exports for American businesses and that conservative Republicans tried to kill has been given a new lease on life, after President Trump changed his position and backed it to compete with China.

title: Closing of Rikers Island Has Residents Wondering What Comes Next
summary: Some people in Queens worry what will take the facility's place and how it will affect their property values. The Rikers Island jail complex in New York City is on track to shutter in 2026, but some Queens residents who live near the island are concerned about what will take its place and how the closing will affect their property values.

title: Crash Probe Promises to Be Especially Difficult
summary: International tensions, suspicion that Iranian missiles could have downed plane complicate investigation. Reports that one or more missiles may have brought down a Ukraine International Airlines jetliner complicate an already tricky international crash investigation into the crash in Iran.

title: Scooter Startup Lime Exits a Dozen Markets, Cuts Jobs
summary: Electric scooter-rental startup cuts 14% of workforce as it seeks profitability. Electric scooter-rental startup Lime is laying off 14% of its workforce as it pulls out of a dozen markets in the U.S. and abroad.

title: Trump's New National Security Team Made Fast Work of Iran Strike
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-President Trump and his senior national-security advisers waited anxiously in the White House Situation Room Tuesday night after intelligence warnings that Iranian missiles would hit two bases the U.S. military uses in Iraq.

title: Trump's Loyal Base in Ohio Supports His Iran Strategy
summary: President's re-election campaign seizes moment to portray him as a strong commander. COLUMBUS, Ohio-As President Trump backs away from conflict with Iran, some of his most loyal supporters say they never worried about the clash getting out of hand.

title: House Approves Resolution Against Use of Force With Iran
summary: Democrats drafted the resolution in a form that would preclude President Trump's veto but it may have no legal force. WASHINGTON-The House passed a largely symbolic measure opposing further military force against Iran without congressional authorization, a day after both Washington and Tehran appeared to back away from military conflict.

title: Amazon in Talks to Sell Streaming TV Ads Outside of Fire TV
summary: Deals would fill some ad inventory on devices including Apple TV and Xbox. Amazon . com Inc. has been building a business selling ads on its Fire streaming television platform. Now, it wants to sell some ads for the first time on other streaming TV systems such as Apple TV and Xbox, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: New York City's School Disciplinary Approach Ties Principals' Hands, Union Says
summary: A union survey showed that only 31% of principals were satisfied with the city's direction in dealing with school safety. Most New York City principals are frustrated by the city Department of Education's push to decrease student suspensions, saying it has led to more disorder in many schools, the principals union said a survey showed.

title: Where You Want to Get Cancer
summary: Mortality rates are falling, especially if you live in the U.S.. Cheer up, folks. For all the political grousing about health-care costs, the good news out this week is that cancer survival rates have improved enormously over the last three decades. The chances of beating most types of cancer are increasing, and that's especially true if you live in the United States.

title: A War Powers Act
summary: House Democrats want to hamstring Trump, not the Iranians.. Fans of the movie "Animal House" will recall the scene when the brothers of Delta House declare that it's time for a "really futile and stupid gesture." House Democrats chose to do something similar with their vote Thursday to block President Trump from using military force against Iran.

title: Taiwan's Hong Kong Election
summary: A Tsai victory would be a blow to Beijing's regional ambitions.. The outcome of America's geopolitical competition with China's Communist Party will hinge in part on the nations of South and East Asia. Will they accede to Beijing's bid for domination of the region or rally to remain independent?

title: Soleimani Had It Coming, but Don't Get Cocky
summary: Do nothing to encourage Iranians' love of country to transfer to loyalty to government. Play it cool.. So far our recent encounter with Iran looks as if it ended pretty well, or as well as it could have. At the moment it looks like we're more or less where we were before Maj. Gen. Qasem Soleimani was killed, only he's gone and that's good. There is no particular reason to believe Iran has been chastened, but it might have been tempered, reminded that there are limits. For the first time in 40 years, since the hostages were taken in the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, the Iranian government took a hard jab from America right in the face. This appears to have left them surprised, rocked back on their heels.

title: There's No Peace From the Doves
summary: Democrats show they've lurched left in foreign as well as domestic policy.. Christmas is over, yet the ghosts of dovish presidential candidates past haunt the Democratic primaries. Eugene McCarthy, George McGovern, Michael Dukakis, John Kerry-these are not kindly, benign spirits; they bring great risks for Democrats in November.

title: Pakistan's Premier Is No Good for India's Secularists
summary: Imran Khan supports protests against the new citizenship law, and hurts the cause in the process.. As demonstrations against a divisive new citizenship law roil India, one thing protesters don't need is support from Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan.

title: In a Concentration Camp, Dreams of a Café
summary: Simon Wiesenthal's story is example of how Jews can find hope in dark times.. Jewish communities have suffered a spate of horrifying anti-Semitic attacks on both sides of the Atlantic. Yet survival has always been the story of the Jewish people. Remembering how previous generations responded to persecution shows how light can still be found amid darkness.

title: 'The Slow Moon Climbs' Review: Beyond Fertility
summary: Menopause is an evolutionary mystery. According to one theory, it arose because post-reproductive women improved the survival rate of children.. In "The Slow Moon Climbs," Susan P. Mattern takes on the ambitious task of exploring "the science, history, and meaning of menopause," a transition for women that has long been associated with endings-of fertility, strength, productivity, sexuality. (Spoiler alert: only fertility need end.) Menopause, she argues, is not a medical matter to be managed with drugs; it is a "developmental transition that has been important to the success of our species," and how women experience it "depends largely, though not entirely, on what their beliefs and expectations are."

title: A Lesson for Today's Tech Trustbusters
summary: The AOL-Time Warner merger was going to dominate the internet. Today both companies barely exist.. It was the biggest corporate merger in history, and it stunned the markets. On Jan. 10, 2000, America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, bid $183 billion for Time Warner, the world's largest content provider. Steve Case, AOL's CEO, talked of "the global company for the internet age." Investor Roger McNamee called the event "transformational." It was widely anticipated to be the start of something significant.
